title: Wildburg Castle
text:
Wildburg Castle is a restored <a href="castle">castle</a> complex in the municipality of <a href="Treis-Karden">Treis-Karden</a> on the <a href="Moselle">Moselle</a> in the district of <a href="Cochem-Zell">Cochem-Zell</a> in the state of <a href="Rhineland-Palatine">Rhineland-Palatine</a> in <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. It is located 30 kilometres south-west of the city of <a href="Koblenz">Koblenz</a>.
Location.
The <a href="hill%20castle">hill castle</a> stands on a rampant, wooded <a href="mountain%20spur">mountain spur</a> surrounded by the <a href="stream">streams</a> Flaumbach and Dünnbach flowing from the <a href="Hunsr%C3%BCck">Hunsrück</a> mountain range, and approximately 85 metres above their <a href="confluence">confluence</a>.
It is neighboured by <a href="Treis%20Castle">Treis Castle</a>, located about 150 metres to the north on the same spur, separated by a <a href="depression%20%28geology%29">depression</a>. 
Wildburg Castle is located at an altitude of 165 metres above sea level in a <a href="side%20valley">side valley</a> to the <a href="Moselle%20Valley">Moselle</a>, and about one kilometre south of <a href="Treis-Karden">Treis</a>.
History.
The exact date of construction is unclear. Possibly Wildburg Castle was built as early as the first half of the 11th century AD by <a href="Count%20Palatine%20of%20the%20Rhine">Count Palatine of the Rhine</a> <a href="Otto%20I%2C%20Count%20of%20Salm">Otto I, Count of Salm</a>, however the sources might refer to neighbouring <a href="Treis%20Castle">Treis Castle</a>.
More likely, Wildburg Castle was built in the 13th or 14th century AD as a seat of the <a href="Burg%20Wildenburg%20%28Eifel%29">Lords of Wildenberg</a>, collateral descendants of the <a href="Braunshorn">Lords of Braunshorn</a>. After the lineage became extinct around 1400 AD, the <a href="Electorate%20of%20Trier">Electorate of Trier</a> seized the castle as a vacant <a href="fief">fief</a>. For the following centuries, Wildburg Castle has been held by various owners on behalf of Trier, amongst them the Lords of Miehlen, the Lords of Burgtor, and the Lords of <a href="Eltz">Eltz</a>.
During the <a href="Nine%20Years%27%20War">Palatine Succession War</a> in 1689, Wildburg Castle was destroyed by the French, along with neighbouring <a href="Treis%20Castle">Treis Castle</a> and many other castles <a href="Left%20Bank%20of%20the%20Rhine">Left Bank of the Rhine</a>. At this point it had lost its strategic significance and has not been rebuilt.
In 1956 its <a href="ruins">ruins</a>, along with those of <a href="Treis%20Castle">Treis Castle</a>, have been acquired by private owners, and Wildburg Castle restored for residential use.
Today.
Wildburg Castle has been preserved since the early 1950s and partially rebuilt for residential use. The northern, almost square <a href="castle%20keep">castle keep</a> has been built-up to its original height and re-roofed. The <a href="hall">hall</a> along with several annexes and <a href="outhouses">outhouses</a> has been rebuilt and made inhabitable for residential use. Remains of other buildings and the <a href="Curtain%20wall%20%28fortification%29">curtain wall</a> have been preserved and form part of today's castle garden.
Currently, Wildburg Castle is inhabited and can only be viewed from outside.
